title: Tuesday, 20th March, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:04am

Hey. Hello. Hi. Good morning.

Soundbuy Morning
Manxish Morning
Pharma Hola
Paper Chase Hullo
BE11:05am

What can we start with? Maybe a break from a picture of a guy in a suit?

GBKrona Hola
BE11:05am

How about ....

11:05 am
BE11:05am

BE11:06am

Andreas Gursky exhibition at the Hayward. See that picture in reproduction form here, http://www.andreas...rks/1999/toys-r-us

BE11:06am

Or better still, go along and see it properly.

J L Morning
11:07 am
BE11:07am

So I mention this apropos of being at Hayward last night for a panel thing about Gursky and the future of photography and that kind of thing.

SoS or as they had in private eye torys-r-us
Miss Piggy FTSE100 lost ~8% YTD
BE11:08am

Four high level university types on stage. And Cambridge Analytica came up about a dozen times, for no obvious reason.

Waterloo Re facebook. Doubt that Cambridge only ones to data mine in such a way. Serious issues here over privacy etc
| Allen L.C. | 你好
BE11:09am

Every time, it was with this scandalised tone that we everyone just knows that they're society's shadowy puppetmasters who are working for the bad guys. It was just assumed that everyone in the room agreed, and I suspect most did.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

At no point did anyone ground the debate on what we're talking about.

BE11:09am

Which is .... "The ability to target advertising at reasonably small cohorts based on an analysis of their expressed preferences, which when used in conjunction with polling data that identifies marginal constituencies might plausibly help political parties use ad budgets more effectively."

BE11:09am

ow did that become the 500 foot bogeyman of our age?

Waterloo How many apps do something similar (most apps seem to require access to work, even if you don't want to give it)
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Yeah, okay, I get that the data harvesting is likely offside, which is clearly bad. We're getting the after effects of that now. But we are talking about a breach of Facebook's T&Cs at best and a bit of unlawful spidering at worst.

erlkin anyone think the geeks at ca are giving themselves a bit too much credit for their ability to shape policy?
BE11:11am

I also get that clandestine methods and marketing agency boasting combine to make a juicy story.

Pharma If you don't want your personal data mined, don't stick it all on the internet. If you don't care, carry on as you were.
BE11:12am

.. particularly when they have a bit of Myers-Briggsy appeals to scientific authority in there. Doubly so when it's scientists gone mad with power and all that. Frankenstein is a good book.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

But .............. I mean ...................

BE11:13am

I find it odd that we (by which I mean the media) have shifted in a year from "we must travel into the depths of middle America and/or middle England and seek to understand this disenfranchised angry underclass" ........

BE11:13am

.... to "egads, behold the mighty power of the puppeteers of democracy who also happen to have stolen all our ad revenue incidentally!"

11:13 am
BE11:13am

I guess the trips to the middle of things weren't wholly successful.

BE11:13am

Anyway.

Flaneur @Pharma - granular data combined with advanced psychological modelling have resulted in the closest thing we have to 'uploading your mind' into a machine. The problem is that you dont have control of it while its there. To say that most people arent even near an rudimentary understanding of these systems is an understatement.
BE11:14am

Let me get a Facebook premarket price ......

Soundbuy The 'disenfranchised angry underclass' are all running around in leased Mercs so don't give a hoot.......
erlkin 171.78
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Down 0.5% life, volume 83k.

Finster The US election system is uniquely attackable in this way, because of the inefficiency, the disparity of the quality of a vote due to redistricting and they way in which the election is held. It is not one man one vote and the Cambridge Analytica methods exploit this fact maximally.
| Allen L.C. | isn't it a good entry point to buy more FB ? i mean.. it's just another data breach and users won't simply give up their social network and gangs...so easily, do they?
BE11:15am

I could put that in dollar terms, as seems to be the fashion as business stories drift further towards the front of a newspaper, but would that really tell us much.

chad_john No, they won't. This story is largely uninteresting to people, but something the media like to get in a tizz about.
| Allen L.C. | @chad_john well said
Finster In a way the US electoral system is like very old idosyncratic code. Hackable.
BE11:16am

Here's a handy list of questions from Morgan Stanley.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

1) What should FB do? 2) Is there growing
regulatory risk? 3) Is there fundamental risk? 4) Has FB's multiple bottomed?

BE11:16am

They're buyers.

Waterloo Is Twitter also open to similar mining?
chad_john The same media wishing of course they had similar nous as they're all banging on about 'micro targeting' with their dwindling ad spend.
BE11:17am

The answer to question one is "be less rubbish at crisis PR", which seems reasonable.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

1) What Can/Should FB Do First? We look for FB to become more assertive about the mistakes it has made, the unintended actions that have occurred on the platform, and how it intends to fix them. We saw GOOGL/YouTube work through multiple difficult issues in 2017 and, in our view, its messaging (see YouTube blog posts) about its mistakes and methods to remedy the errors helped turn the company narrative and sentiment among investors/advertisers with minimal (if any) impact on user growth and engagement. We look for FB to act in a similar way , most specifically by imposing stronger restrictions, safeguards and explanation around user data (and of users’ friends’ data), how FB is using the data, and how data are made available to app developers/third parties through the API and Facebook Connect. This last aspect could have a negative impact on Facebook Audience Network’s ability to scale, but 1) we believe this is an immaterial percent of the business now and 2) we do not have any material contribution in our model.

Pharma @Flaneur, my mind was pretty much encapsulated by The Hobbit on a ZX Spectrum.Incidentally, did you read the weekend piece in the Guardian about the difficulty of filling jobs in the restaurant sector. Mentioned a number of factors, but the only reference to pay was in a sidebar on cost pressures, citing "increase in minimum wage". Now, I wonder why restaurants can't find the staff.
TheManwithaLongChin yes but twitter's user base isn't varied enough to be valuable imo
Cynical Answer to MS Question 2 is yes
Miss Piggy #CambridgeAnalytica: "Destabilise a multinational by manipulating its stock, beep, done." https://www.youtube.com/embed/FumW4wuqDeQ?start=354&end=400
chad_john So yes, buy Facebook. IMO.
BE11:18am

Will we get more regulation? Yes, probably. But as a colleague pointed out yesterday, regulation tends to be good for incumbents.

Flaneur @Chad_john - the media are in a tizz because the efficacy of these systems is orders of magnitude ahead of what the MSM can produce in opinon or advertising. They can simulate responses in their models and effect them in the real world and they are totally unregulated.Perhaps the old media has a point, just not the one they wanted to make?
chad_john I think it's more jealousy, Flaneur.
Electric Dragon Data Protection Act, BE. It is illegal to pass data onto third parties without explicit consent to do so (this is most likely to apply to the data of FB "friends" of users of this survey app).
BE11:19am

Ordinarily, regulation raises the wall a bit for the leaders. For their challengers, the wall gets a hell of a lot higher.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Back to MOST.

chad_john Trouble is Electric Dragon, nobody reads the T&Cs.
Otter Hello Friendos
BE11:20am

[The threat of regulation] only furthers the impetus for FB to begin to improve its messaging (take control of the public message), self-regulate and improve the safeguards on its platform. Europe is set to enact GDPR on 5/25 (see What We Don't Know about GDPR) and continued headlines like these increase the chance that 1) more Europeans will choose to opt out of sharing data with FB and 2) similar data sharing safe guards could be brought to the US. While we can debate the earnings impact (potentially low) there is little debating that these risks are likely to continue to weigh on FB's multiple.

Miss Piggy Sell Facebook, the trend is broken.
| Allen L.C. | So what's up with Uber's auto pilot ? The ruling's gonna impact AI &autonomous driving in a big way...
Mouselet Good morning miscellaneous assorted people
Pharma @Electric Dragon, haven't most FB users given consent when they tick the "share data with selected partners" box? (guessing there is one, or similar; not on FB)
Mouselet Uber's PR machine is working well and saying 'the pedestrian stepped out from the shadows in front of the car how can we be expected to have seen her it's not as if thermal imaging cameras exist'
BE11:21am

(@Electric Dragon: yes, as I said, it's a breach of T&Cs at best and of data laws at worst. The angle that it's unpicking the seams of democratic process is what sticks in my gullet a wee bit.)

Mouselet I would have thought that getting a GDPR ruling against Facebook would make the careers of half of Brussels
FATDAZ @BE re CA well said
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Part three: earnings.

erlkin i think i read where CA found they could identify 32 different types of humans via what they "liked"
BE11:21am

3) Is There a Current Fundamental Risk to Revenue or EPS? No, in our view, not as of now...and we’re not changing our $7.24/$9.53 ‘18/’19 GAAP EPS forecast. But
this drumbeat of negative news and headlines increases the risk that there is some user backlash and a negative feedback loop. This increases the chance that users become more hesitant to give FB their data and/or use FB as frequently… which would also likely lead to an eventual advertiser backlash. This is the most important trend to monitor, as weaker user or ad growth are the most material risks to the stock.

BE11:22am

And part four: buy buy buy buy buy.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

4) Is FB's Multiple at a Bottom? Yes...but this isn't new. FB's multiple has indeed compressed….now trading at 18X our 2019 GAAP EPS for 30%+ Y/Y growth. It is cheaper than GOOGL, EBAY, and many other assets across the S&P that are growing more slowly and/or (in our view) don't have as much long-term monetization potential (across Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, Whatsapp, etc.). That said, FB's ability to garner a higher multiple, in our view, is likely to be determined by its ability to improve the narrative and to help investors/users/advertisers feel confident that there is not a structural "data" risk to engagement or monetization

Mouselet That seems not an unreasonable number of principle components (five, given 32) to pull noisily out of fifty million vectors
chad_john I can guarantee very, very, very few ad agencies/businesses are sat this morning planning to spend less with Facebook based on this.
FATDAZ @erlkin that work was done independently as academic research with roots as far back as 2009 I believe
| Allen L.C. | Just wondering how many shares outstanding of Facebook are associated with ETF products...
BE11:23am

There's lots of that kind of thing around. I picked MOST simply because it was the neatest, but what's clear is that no one is changing their views here. Not on the sellside at least.

erlkin oil up and broad markets down seems to be a new trend....?
Pharma @mouselet "principal" (with apologies)
Mouselet Principal components analysis of political surveys was being done by Chris Lightfoot for fun over a weekend in 2005
BE11:24am

Pivotal, for instance, who are sellers, still don't use this as a stick to beat FB.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

We continue to rate FB stock Sell with a $152 YE2018 price target. While concerns such as those mentioned in this note are potential headwinds to the company’s business, our negative call is still primarily informed by a view that says there are limits to the company’s growth (and for digital advertising more generally) relative to the size of the overall advertising economy. In parallel, we think costs and capital expenditures will continue to rise as the company grows and makes efforts to sustain its user base and support ongoing revenue growth.

Mouselet I mean, these are not novel forms of statistical wizardry and machine learning; this is applying absolutely standard techniques to interesting new datasets
Miss Piggy If Facebook gets linked to Trump and trade wars and lost of prosperity (coz that is what happens in a trade war) then Facebook becomes toxic. Sell.
BE11:24am

But that's probably enough on that.

FATDAZ @mouselet indeed
BE11:25am

I'll step back from the subject and allow the rest of the media to disappear off over the horizon in pursuit of a MacGuffin.

11:25 am
undefined
Mouselet I suppose Facebook priced as an underlying utility without the ability to sell adverts is not worth all that much; it might manage to charge a fiver a month in the UK and a pound a month in Indonesia
Mouselet Tools for social primates
BE11:26am

Meanwhile, in London: conveyor belts!

red 95% of social media a waste of time for 95% of the users
BE11:26am

Michelin comes in with 610p per share cash.

Mouselet Yes, but primates need wastes of time; most of the baboons grooming by the waterhole are not getting significantly deloused thereby
Soundbuy Sure I remember Fenner's PWs been covered here.............
FATDAZ @red a chance to live life vicariously through the experiences of others
11:27 am
BE11:27am

31% premium to Friday's closing price, which the statement flags up, rather than Monday's closing price, which popped 5% late on after this leaked into the market.

Finster Facebook has just been flagged as a source for a hostile intelligence OP in democratic heartland US (at least gross neglicience in their interactions with CA). This will not be pretty. (disclosure: No position).
Mouselet in much the same way as talking round the water-cooler, or reading books, or listening to the blind bard by the fire telling that catchy poem about the wrath of Achilles again ...
red @FATDAZyes what a sad way to live and yet many do so freely, mostly because they are unable to make fruit of their own lives
BE11:28am

Hang on, did Fenner not autoprice? One moment.

Fenner PLC (FENR:LSE): Last: 614.00, up 123.4 (+25.15%), High: 624.50, Low: 610.50, Volume: 7.63m
Finster negligence even.
11:28 am
BE11:28am

There we are.

Mouselet I do not want to have as many babies as I would need to have that many baby pictures in my own life!
BE11:29am

Price looks pretty good, though not unbeatable, hence us trading through the terms.

Miss Piggy #Brexit, #WithdrawalAgreement: I am pleased to see Iain Duncan Smith and Nigel Farage displeased.
FATDAZ @BE interesting that Michelin should bid just a commodity / mining cycle may be turning lower
BE11:29am

One idea is that Fenner would be worth more to two buyers than one, so you could get a financial buyer or a Melrose type coming in.

red @Finsterpretty sure negligence will be in there but as long as they keep bringing home the bacon, the market is going to chalk this one off as well. only government intervention is going to skin this cat for good. and while thats not apparent, its btfd, as all the FANGS
11:30 am
BE11:30am

In terms of industrial buyers that'd want both bits ..... Caterpillar maybe? But not many others.

BE11:30am

Here's UBS.

BE11:30am

In multiples it equates to 13x 2018E EBITDA, 18x EBITA (August year end). This falls to 12x and 15x respectively on our 2019E forecasts. This looks high versus the 7-8x EBITDA paid by Continental for Veyence a few years ago, but reflects in our opinion the higher growth profile of the AEP business at Fenner. The valuation being paid is in line with multiples paid for other UK engineers that have been acquired in recent years. In the context of Fenner having traded at an average 20-25% sector discount over the last decade this could seem a generous multiple. However, we would note that our 2018E EBITA is still only c70% of the 2012 peak profits and even if the past ECS peak may not be repeatable we do see further strong improvement forecast to 2020E.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Though note the multiple comes back to better levels on £30m of synergies, which clearly a financial buyer wouldn't have in the short term.

J L @Red: one acronym per post please..
BE11:32am

We do not foresee any competition or regulator related barriers. The other question is whether there could be a counterbid at all?
While there are companies that could have a strategic fit with Fenner's divisions individually it is not obvious to us that there is a third party that would have the same strategic logic to bid for the whole group.

red @Miss Piggythe agreement is only good til they part ways, be it on march 2019 or prior to. essentially nothing was written in stones yesterday. its a set of vague conditions which allow talks to move on, but at any moment if those talks fail, the transition agreement falls apart too.
Mouselet buy the fromulent dip?
1 bid at 2 FENNER-Rec.cash offer from Michelin,610p/sh.We are buyers at 610p.........+25%....fairly strong wording in my Investec morning note BE..
Miss Piggy @red:sure
Finster @red: you're probably right, but the lawmakers very path to power is threatened. To them it is mission critical and they will come down very hard on facebook. This reminds me of the Solomon Brothers/FED scandal and similar: It's angering your political superior and directly humiliating them.
BE11:32am

And Citigroup.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

The proposed deal multiple is 12.6x 2018E EV/EBITDA (pre-
synergies). Given Continental purchased Goodyear’s engineered products business
in 2015 we do not believe a counter-offer from Continental is likely. On the other
hand, Bridgestone already has a mining tyres, conveyor belting and hoses business
so the complementary argument is not as compelling as it is for Michelin.

FATDAZ Re FENR a look at long-term chart vs the FTSE 350 miners suggests the clues were there https://i.gyazo.com/9561bc6ea106db7beef5b18bcc4a5cd9.png
Miss Piggy Oh dear, "Jacob Rees-Mogg, chair of the European Research Group, is planning to lead a protest of Brexit supporting MPs on Wednesday, who will board a boat and throw fish out as they pass by parliament."
BE11:33am

And Stifel.

BE11:33am

Our first take
is that the deal looks good, and offers a healthy premium, especially in light of Fenner’s
very strong recent share price performance. We wonder if some shareholders may want
more however, given the offer is all-cash and in light of Fenner's strong recent underlying
performance, although see few other potential buyers for the entire business currently

11:33 am
BE11:34am

The outlier is Investec.

Finster But it's in the nature of Facebook that they did it more like road kill without an afterthought. There was just no reflection about how far this can go or the damage done by the access granted to CA.
red @Finsterin a way the presnt us administration has facebook to thank for where they are today, so not sure they will really want to change anything, although being seen to be doing "something" (going through motions) would be worth their while.
J L @Miss Piggy: he's not touched a fish in his life!
BE11:34am

With margins below the sector average, we considered that its valuation should also be below average. However, Fenner is clearly worth more to Michelin than it is as a stand-alone. The immediate synergies could perhaps be matched by other rubber/polymer companies, making Fenner attractive also to other parties.

1 bid at 2 @FATDAZ Hope you were on board - it was my largest holding.
GBKrona @Miss Pigergy - JR-M is very fishy in the best of times. How apt.
chad_john @Miss Piggy presumably not a Sturgeon.
Soundbuy Red Herrings
FATDAZ @1 bid at 2 well done you
Finster @red: for how much longer will the present government coalition control congress? I wouldn't bet beyond the mid terms.
red i like head of kpmg take on the transition deal. since nothing is yet signed, people are going to continue planning for no deal until proven to the contrary.
Miss Piggy @Soundbuy: Red herrings is more Jeremy Corbyn.
BE11:35am

Argument here is that if Michelin can take out £30m of costs immediately, including a pretty amazing £9m of unallocated costs, then so can others.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

The question is whether other rubber and polymer product companies (think of Bridgestone, Freudenberg, Pirelli or Trelleborg) would be able to find similar synergies and be attracted enough by Fenner's markets and prospects to crash the party. We think that this is a possibility and we move our target price (including takeover premium) to the back-stop level of Michelin's offer.

red @Finsterthats above my pay grade, im just here to buy the dip ;)
BE11:36am

Which seems to be the take the market wants to believe right now. We're up to 617p live.

undefined
Electric Dragon The hon. member for the 18th century has finally gone completely nuts.
Bonnemort At least he won't be flicking V-signs a la Geldof?
1 bid at 2 Soph? Going the way of MCRO ...as we enter the game of who's shoe is going to drop next ?
11:38 am
BE11:38am

So .......... what else we got?

BE11:39am

Sophos still getting smashed out of sight.

Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 428.60, down 30.4 (-6.62%), High: 467.40, Low: 423.00, Volume: 1.58m
erlkin rbc repeats buy on BP
11:39 am
BE11:39am

This is in part the Micro Focus effect. They have notable similarities ....

Miss Piggy #Fish: How can you tell EU to sod off over the catching of fish when you need to sell EU 85% of your catch. Cakeism.
BE11:40am

.... such as loads of debt from acquisitions and a reliance on licence revenue that, it often turns out, can be less reliable than the likes of Sage might have us believe.

Otter @Miss Piggy you could freeze it and sell it to china as fish fingers
1 bid at 2 Hopefully SCT results tomorrow will not have Mcro effect.
BE11:41am

We've also got Sophos's .... peculiarities, let's call them, which we've mentioned here many times.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Such as its preference for Cash EBITDA as an earnings measure.

red insider selling pre to this period of softness also telling as often is
Forester If fisherman are cheesed off, wait until farmer's realise the true effect of Brexit when they stick their hands out to farm-loathing HMT whilst trying to fight off cheap US imports!
red you can make excuses for the bottom line but if the top lines not there a tech comp has nothing to fall back on.
Miss Piggy Ah, Rees Mogg rows back, he denies this Torygraph story https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2018/03/19/jacob-rees-mogg-fling-fish-trawler-thames-protest-fishermen/
BE11:43am

And clearly, companies that invent their own earnings measure aren't for everyone. That kind of thing gives management a wall of trust to climb, and that's not easy when your last set of numbers were considerably worse than expected due to what you claim are sales phasing problems.

Miss Piggy "hake news"
red earnings disappointment are getting punished badly in terms of share price reaction, thats been a theme for a while now.
chad_john *claps*
Waterloo Last I heard they were screaming that they need access to single market as that's where they sell most fish.. Having seem them sail up the Thames blasting out hope and glory, I have zero sympathy.
Soundbuy Now we have LBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA.........zzzzz
BE11:44am

Anyway, much of yesterday's damage can be pinned on Northern Trust Capital Markets, who no longer have Neil Campling but still seem to be living under his halo when it comes to tech stocks.

Blank canvas Any insights into Virgin Money?
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Here's Ameet Patel.

BE11:45am

We’d been buyers of Sophos since IPO in June 2015 all the way up to their latest update on 8 Feb – it is an easy story to understand and buy into as Europe’s only mid-cap pure play on the cyber security mega theme. That’s all very well as long there is no change in the narrative and strong growth momentum – but the slowdown in growth reported in Q3 rang alarm bells for us. Yes, management was keen to point out this was in-line with expectations, had been flagged as potential consequence of new product launches, and would be reversed in Q4. Perhaps – we’ll see at the FY release in May. But in the meantime, we think at the very least the bare bones investment case could come under increasing scrutiny – and then a few things add to our concerns. First, it’s another roll-up/leverage combo (net debt/FY18 consensus EBITDA is a punchy 4x, $244M cumulative spend on acquisitions to date on cumulative FCF of $151M) – that alone could get investors thinking, especially after Micro Focus this morning and Sophos’s top line wobble in February. Second, there’s plenty to dig into on the accounting front – not least the reliance on prepayments, high ratio of deferred revenues/revenues, and the company’s definition of ‘cash EBITDA’. And more generically, although demand growth remains strong, this is a competitive space and any sign of intensifying pressure (pricing or otherwise) could trigger fears re top line momentum – if Sophos has for any reason struggled to recover from the sales disruption experienced in Q3 and Q4 ends up disappointing, we’d expect serious capitulation.

chad_john Anything on Bon Marche? Seems to have been hit this morning, doesn't seem to be sector as it survived the other retail tumbles.
BE11:45am

On balance, we think there’s enough here for investors to question at least in the near term, especially with valuation at a level which could make the stock particularly sensitive to any cracks in the story (EV/Sales 5.4x, EV/EBITDA 57x on FY18 consensus numbers). We initiate with a Trading Sell.

Waterloo Virgin money. Is that another name fro Crypto?
Pharma @Forester, given farmers are ~2% of the population, and the rest of use could get much cheaper food, I look forward to the day.(the Common Fisheries Policy was a stitch up however, and should be ditches as soon as possible)
11:46 am
undefined

red yes cant argue with that re sophos summary
1 bid at 2 Anyone been talking about Mortgage approvals or the lack of for the main reason for weak retail sales ...looking at the notable results forthcoming. KGF, NXT

Oh, and should note a few knife catchers have appeared on Micro Focus.

Micro Focus International PLC (MCRO:LSE): Last: 1,028, up 16.5 (+1.63%), High: 1,085, Low: 980.20, Volume: 3.39m
Pharma @Forester, so carry on with the payments, and call them something else. Hardly rocket science.@Bonnemort, yes, the invention of the Danish fishing industry was one of the worst aspects of a rotten system.
red @ 1 bid at 2uk retail sales thurs i think. tomorrow its jobs and wages. inflation was soft today, if wages soft the bottom could fall out come thursday
Soundbuy Mending nets by candlelight as a 5 yr old causes lasting damage......
BE11:50am

Credit Suisse both saying it's fallen enough, even if you don't believe management, which seems to be the sensible approach right now.

BE11:50am

Numis is even more brave, turning buyers.

Miss Piggy #Brexit: Scottish politicos have won court appeal to get ECJ to adjudicate on whether revokiong Article 50 is possible https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2018/mar/20/brexit-wont-cut-overall-prices-in-shops-for-consumers-says-institute-for-fiscal-studies-politics-live#block-5ab0f3d5e4b06194ea77e55a
11:50 am
BE11:50am

The fall in the Micro Focus share price, while an understandable emotional reaction, looks substantially overdone. The group has no balance sheet issues. Furthermore, SUSE, SaaS and maintenance revenues give the business inherent stability, which means that apparently reasonable top-down downside scenarios actually require
implausible reductions in licence sales. Calling the precise path of revenues is of course difficult. However we model a CY20 FCF yield of 16.5% and dividend yield of 8.6%, which we think are compelling.

Forester @Paharma farmers are very nervous that Treasury has a long-standing dislike of subsidies (which mainly goes to the big landowners). Those in "free markets" like my mate who is a spud baron are optimistic. Dairy, upland farmers etc are really nervous.
red @Miss Piggyi think ECJ has said it wishes not to rule on what the UK should decide for itself.
BE11:52am

Current valuation suggests "implausible" licence declines and ignores SUSE, which is a quarter of the valuation. Plus no debt repayment for 3.5 years on a business that's had no problems historically with cash generation .....

red I don't think it could ever rule in favour of such a standing, just imagine what it would do to negotiations
BE11:52am

..... so you're getting, what, 7% yield currently?

11:53 am
BE11:53am

I can see the logic, I guess.

undefined
1 bid at 2 Purp? Continues to release air..
BE11:55am

Not up to speed on this Virgin Money deal, sorry @Blank canvas. Once I am I'll add a line or two here: https://www.ft.com...-9b4b-bc4b9f08f381

Soundbuy Polypipe - any grey?
11:56 am
BE11:56am

Nothing new on Purplebricks either, sorry @1 Bid. To explain why it's going down we'd also have to explain why it went up, and that's not easy.

Blank canvas BE: Thanks

Polypipe has reported record full-year results, with underlying PBT 8% ahead of the prior year. New build residential has again been a star performer and there should be few surprises that RMI remains relatively subdued. The group’s broad mix of end markets and leading brand should continue to support growth ahead of the UK construction market, and overall trading in the new year is ahead of 2017. We have trimmed our top-end PBT forecasts by c5%, reflecting some contract delays in commercial and infrastructure and a modest margin reduction. Polypipe remains a key growth play in the sector and we maintain our Buy recommendation.

BE12:05pm

No matter how tight a corner 888 finds itself in, it always seems to find a way out. In 2017 it faced challenges in the UK and market withdrawals, and yet it has reported 12% EBITDA growth today. If it exits Germany in 2018, the revenue loss should be offset by strong growth in regulated markets.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Following the publication of a ruling from the German Federal Administrative Court last week, 888 is “assessing the status and breadth of its offerings in the German market”. The court held that the German State treaty, which, inter alia, prohibits online casino and poker, is lawful. Until now 888, and others, have relied on the view that the State treaty was unlawful under EU law. 888’s options include a petition (appeal) to the German Federal Constitutional Court.

 A full, or partial withdrawal from Germany is a possibility. Other operators have withdrawn. Payment institutions are considering their position and those accounting for 9% of 888’s deposits have decided to stop providing services. We estimate the potential EBITDA impact of a withdrawal in the range of 5-10% although we note that that previous market withdrawals by 888 have resulted in the reallocation of resources to growth in other markets.
